moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6
comment: He seems to have absorbed the Kasparov-Kramnik games with this opening and feels it's safe enough in this event. He's probably not more ambitious than to hope for a draw in his games with the Black pieces.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8
comment: Black has achieved much of his plan to develop Bc8-g4 and clear the way for Ra8-d8. But, this does nothing for Bf8 and Rh8 AND Bg4 is a little vulnerable to White's king-side pawns. White has to find a way to keep Pc2 safe (as usual) as he chases Bg4 back -- bringing more pawns to the aid of Pe5, so White can force another line opening before Black can get Bf8 & Rh8 developed.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8 12. Bb2 Nd5 13. h3 Bf5 14. g4 Bd7 15. Ne2 h5
comment: Just when White appears to have his pawns storming up the board Black undermines them, and before Ne2-g3 could secure square h5!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8 12. Bb2 Nd5 13. h3 Bf5 14. g4 Bd7 15. Ne2 h5 16. c4 Nb4 17. Rad1
comment: One should never assume Adams (in particular) ever makes a move such as this without some intention. Black can respond to Rad1 and leave ...hxg4 for later.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8 12. Bb2 Nd5 13. h3 Bf5 14. g4 Bd7 15. Ne2 h5 16. c4 Nb4 17. Rad1 hxg4 18. Nxf7 Kxf7 19. Rxd7+ Ke6 20. Rxc7 Nd3 21. Bd4 Rxh3
comment: Though Pb7 is en prise it appears Black's pieces are all active enough and White's seem uncoordinated. That might change in a few moves though; the position is quite fluid.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8 12. Bb2 Nd5 13. h3 Bf5 14. g4 Bd7 15. Ne2 h5 16. c4 Nb4 17. Rad1 hxg4 18. Nxf7 Kxf7 19. Rxd7+ Ke6 20. Rxc7 Nd3 21. Bd4 Rxh3 22. Be3 g5
comment: guarding against Ne2-f4+, so he can capture Pe5

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. b3 Bg4 11. Ng5 Ke8 12. Bb2 Nd5 13. h3 Bf5 14. g4 Bd7 15. Ne2 h5 16. c4 Nb4 17. Rad1 hxg4 18. Nxf7 Kxf7 19. Rxd7+ Ke6 20. Rxc7 Nd3 21. Bd4 Rxh3 22. Be3 g5 23. Rxb7 Nxe5 24. Kg2
comment: I suspect White still has some advantage because Ke6 is exposed and Black's pawns are split. But, Adams might have been in some time pressure or he may not have seen any specific way to make headway. And, with a draw they both remain tied for the lead, at this early point of the tournament.
